posts.name: Ryan
posts.cooked: Our team doesn’t usually color our robot, but for future seasons, we’ve been exploring more options. It seems relatively straightforward to anodize aluminum using materials we have in the lab. A helpful resource on this topic is the *DIY Step-by-Step Guide on How to Anodize Aluminum* from [SendCutSend](https://sendcutsend.com/blog/diy-anodizing-in-10-steps/). We’re curious about the benefits of anodizing compared to powder coating and whether it impacts bearing tolerances. Does anodizing offer advantages over powder coating, and how does it affect precision and fitting?

link_counts.title: A DIY Step-by-Step Guide on How to Anodize Aluminum | SendCutSend

posts.name: diego
posts.cooked: Powder coating, if done by a non-professional, may not be evenly thick, so results can vary. To ensure optimal coverage, it's best to check for any bearing holes and address them beforehand. Our team plans to explore spray-painting as an alternative next year since it offers a sleek appearance when done correctly and remains cost-effective. This could be another viable option to consider.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Personally, I would never attempt DIY anodizing. The required chemicals, such as sulfuric acid, lye, and lead, pose significant safety risks. Additionally, properly disposing of these substances safely and legally can be challenging. It’s much easier and safer to opt for powder coating or spray painting instead.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: They are not things I would let kids be around, but there are standard procedures for neutralizing bases and acids—it’s why we’re all dragging boxes of baking soda from one end of the country to the other. Most of you are too young to remember the days before sealed maintenance-free car batteries—you’d have to measure your acid/water level and strength and potentially top it up.

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: Anodizing, for FIRST Robotics Competition purposes, has no impact on weight or tolerances. However, the process involves harsh chemicals and is generally not recommended for FIRST Robotics Competition teams to perform in-house.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: Many of these chemicals are restricted in California, as far as I recall (IIRC). Proper surface preparation, using a rattlecan, should be the best approach.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: There are two other options, both are low weight and durable. Cerakote, a global leader in thin-film ceramic coatings, offers specialized finishes for various industries including automotive, aerospace, industrial, consumer electronics, sports, and fitness. Their products provide long-lasting protection and resistance, making them ideal for a wide range of applications. You can explore their gallery and find certified applicators near you. Another excellent choice is duracoatfirearmfinishes.com, which offers similar high-quality solutions tailored for different needs.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

link_counts.title: Cerakote.com - Global Leader in Thin-Film Ceramic Coatings | Cerakote

posts.name: Co-Head Mentor 3658
posts.cooked: My teams have built every robot I’ve been part of over the past six seasons. I set up a DIY powder coating station in my garage and even converted an old hot dog warmer from a high school cafeteria into a functional powder coating oven. While powder coating isn’t overly difficult, it does require practice and is relatively affordable. Despite all this, I’ve always admired how cool custom paint jobs look on hot rods and cars, and I believe the same applies to robots. Over the past three years, my teams have won multiple Quality and Industrial Design awards—often because of our powder-coated finishes. Judges have specifically highlighted the color choices in our winning robots, proving that powder coating plays a significant role in their success. Painting, often called “rattle-can painting,” doesn’t appeal to me much, and it’s easy to see why it’s considered less durable—it tends to chip easily. I’d highly recommend learning the basics of powder coating to any team looking to achieve professional-looking, long-lasting finishes. Awards truly do reflect real quality!

reply_to_user.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Chase Eid
posts.cooked: Maxtube works great with paint. I guess it's how it's manufactured—it causes small lines on the aluminum that the paint can get into, making it stay on better than unsanded sheet metal.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
I don’t deny that powder coating is great—it is. I’m simply offering alternatives. Cerakote offers a "cold" series (air dry) for teams that don’t have access to ovens. The key difference lies in cure time. They also provide various series for those who either have or prefer oven-cured options.  

Additionally, I don’t work for Cerakote nor have I used their products personally.  

EDIT: Cerakote requires only about 1 millimeter (0.001 inches) of coating, which is minimal.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Ardiano Works
posts.cooked:
Anodizing is generally thinner than powder coating, and there are various levels of anodization available. Hard anodize provides superior surface hardness but offers fewer color options compared to regular anodizing. On the other hand, powder coating is thicker. When applying powder coating to a frame, it’s often necessary to mask the bearing holes to prevent them from clogging the coating process.  

While I wouldn’t attempt DIY anodizing myself, I’d likely contact a local plating company for assistance. If you’re not particular about color options, black anodized finishes are commonly used and may even be sponsored by companies if you’re willing to take the risk of letting them test your parts.  

For powder coating or cerakote, I would recommend attempting it yourself, though you’ll need access to a sufficiently large oven. Household ovens, such as those found in junk yards, are typically too small for this purpose. Cerakote is appealing due to its thin application and wide range of color choices, while still offering durability. However, proper surface preparation is essential to ensure adhesion and a successful finish.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked: Cerakote air cure takes hours to become tack-free and around 5 days to fully cure. Plus, it has a strong, unpleasant smell similar to burning urinal cakes and poses a significant inhalation risk. I use Cerakote for both personal enjoyment and practical reasons, but I would **not** recommend it for robot parts, even if the test pieces I've used look fantastic. Similarly, I wouldn’t advise anodizing aluminum in-house either, despite the potential benefits, due to the messy chemicals involved and the additional steps required, like dyeing and sealing the parts afterward. You can create your own anodized titanium finish using water, baking soda, and a voltage range of 10-120 volts at less than 1A. We successfully achieved a nice blue color on titanium wire by applying about 30 volts. The rest of our robot setup involves some preparatory work, and while it looks great on live streams, it doesn’t hold up as well under close inspection in the pits. However, this trade-off between time, budget, and results seems acceptable for most competition teams.

posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked: You can also use vinyl to wrap parts, similar to how it’s used for cars and buses. While it may not be as durable as some alternatives, vinyl can still be used in various patterns or solid colors. Additionally, a number of factors may allow certain parts to be wrapped once they are already attached to the robot.

posts.name: Ardiano Works
posts.cooked: Was there any surface preparation on this Air Cure Cerakote? We weren't aware of its existence before. We had to perform an oxide blast, which required personal protective equipment (PPE) and specific filtration. Afterward, we wiped everything clean before applying the spray and then moved it into the oven.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked: It has to be as clean as possible to achieve optimal results. Steps to prepare the metal include degreasing, sandblasting or abrading, applying a propane torch to certain parts, degreasing again, and waiting a moment for steel, though aluminum must be coated immediately to prevent oxidation. The finish needs to be flawless since Cerakote does not hide imperfections.

posts.name: JohnD 3322
posts.cooked: Check for a local shop that does anodizing. There’s a good chance they’ll in-kind sponsor you by providing free anodizing. Don’t expect a quick turnaround, though, so we typically send a few tubes early in the season and then machine-anodize them afterward. This process gives a good two-tone finish, with shiny holes, and there’s always a Sharpie available if you want to get the color back.

posts.name: 829 The Digital Goats Official Curmudgeon.
posts.cooked:
Anodizing removes a thin layer of material from parts. However, the racks used for holding these parts become too thin over time and may need replacement. If a part undergoes multiple anodizing processes, it generally won’t affect its tolerances unless specifically designed otherwise.  

We’re fortunate to have a local anodizing company in Indianapolis that serves many area teams. A big shout-out goes to Colors Inc. for their excellent work!

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
Anodizing does remove a thin layer of material, but the parts themselves do not get smaller; instead, they expand slightly due to the oxide layer formation. This process doesn't affect tolerances significantly unless anodized multiple times.  

This understanding is incomplete. Anodizing converts part of the base material into an oxide layer, causing minimal expansion—often in micrometers—making it imperceptible to most users. In contrast, aluminum anodizing can add thicknesses of up to 0.004 to 0.005 inches. This can lead to issues with press-fit pins and bolt holes becoming too tight.  

I repair anodizing racks for a local company. These racks, typically made of titanium, usually break from mechanical stress rather than wear or rust.  

Titanium anodizing alters dimensions by a few nanometers to micrometers, often undetectable without precise measurement tools. Aluminum anodizing can thicken by 0.004 to 0.005 inches, enough to impact fitments and create overly tight bolt holes.  

It seems you might be confusing etching, a preparatory step for anodizing, with the anodizing process itself. Manufacturers may machine parts slightly underspec so that the oxide layer's expansion brings them back into tolerance or within acceptable ranges.  

Less durable materials in certain etching baths can degrade over time, potentially affecting rack longevity.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked:
Sure! Here's the cleaned-up version:

"I would suggest it for robot parts, even if the test parts I did looked amazing. Wouldn’t, right?"

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked: Cerakote air cure takes hours to be tack-free and around 5 days to cure. Plus, it smells like burning urinal cakes. See, this is why they won’t let you do marketing! What a great description. To stay on topic, I’m all in on rattle cans—90% of the bang with a super low entry point regarding skill and equipment requirements.
